message_1: A rectangular tank contains water up to a height of 3 meters. If the length of the tank is 4 meters and the width is 2 meters, what is the pressure at the bottom of the tank? (Assume that atmospheric pressure is negligible and the density of water is 1000 kg/m³)
message_2:
To find the pressure at the bottom of the tank, we can use the formula for hydrostatic pressure:

P = ρgh

where P is the pressure, ρ (rho) is the density of the fluid (water in this case), g is the acceleration due to gravity (approximately 9.81 m/s²), and h is the height of the fluid column.

Given the density of water (ρ) is 1000 kg/m³ and the height of the water column (h) is 3 meters, we can plug these values into the formula:

P = (1000 kg/m³)(9.81 m/s²)(3 m)

P = 29430 kg·m²/s²·m³

Since 1 Pascal (Pa) is equal to 1 kg·m²/s²·m³, the pressure at the bottom of the tank is:

P = 29430 Pa
